misconceptions.name: Implemented a different physics acceleration problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes average acceleration from initial and final velocities and time, instead of reading 5 integers and printing the sum of the even ones. The entire algorithm and output are for a different problem than the one assigned.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t, computes (v1 - v0) / t as acceleration, and print that as the final result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, examine each to see if it is even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Reads 3 numeric values only, not 5
Computes (v1 - v0) / t and labels it 'average acceleration'
Final output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reused code or misread the assignment, solving a physics acceleration exercise instead of the specified even-number summation problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design your algorithm from the requirements: you must (1) read 5 integers, (2) decide which are even using n % 2 == 0, (3) keep a running sum of those even values, and (4) print that sum with the required label.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (input prompts, variable names, computation, output text) refers to acceleration and not to summing even numbers, so it clearly targets a different problem.

evidence.note: Code is computing and printing an average acceleration, not summing even numbers as required.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads exactly three double values (v0, v1, t) using nextDouble(), instead of reading five integers as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to read three numeric values (v0, v1, and t) as doubles from the user for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read five integer values from the user. Using Scanner, this typically means calling nextInt() five times (often inside a loop) to obtain all required integers.
symptoms: Input prompt mentions only three values
Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
No code to read five separate integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment between the problem requirements and the implemented input handling, possibly due to copying an example that reads v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to read integers with nextInt(). Ensure you read exactly five integers, either with five calls or with a loop that repeats five times.
related_concepts: Matching input type and count to problem specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and the three nextDouble() calls clearly indicate that the student is only reading three doubles, not five integers.

evidence.note: Reads only three values as doubles, contrary to the requirement to read five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop or conditional logic for filtering even numbers and accumulating a sum
misconceptions.description: The code does not use any loop to process multiple inputs or any conditional (e.g., n % 2 == 0) to filter even numbers. It performs a single arithmetic computation on three inputs instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: Once I read my three values, I can perform one formula computation and print the result; I do not need looping or conditional checks for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To solve the problem, the program should iterate over the five inputs (using a loop), check each with a condition like if (n % 2 == 0) to determine if it is even, and add only those even numbers to a running sum before printing the final sum.
symptoms: No loop constructs (for, while, do-while) in the program
No modulus operator (%) or if-statement to test evenness
Single computation (v1 - v0) / t instead of repeated processing of multiple values
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a single-formula physics calculation rather than designing a loop-and-condition based solution for aggregating selected values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a loop that runs five times. Inside the loop, read an integer, check if it is even with n % 2 == 0, and if so add it to a sum variable. After the loop, print the sum.
related_concepts: Even-number checking with the modulus operator
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The program contains no loop, no conditionals, and no modulus operator, so it cannot be implementing the required 'sum of even numbers' logic.

evidence.note: Performs a single arithmetic computation and output; no loop, accumulator, or even-number conditional logic is present anywhere in the code.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Address Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of implementing the logic required for Q1 (Sum of Even Numbers). The submission lacks all required elements: reading 5 integers, a loop structure, conditional checking for even numbers, and sum accumulation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the solution for a different, likely physics-related, assignment (Acceleration Calculator) by mistake, or misunderstood the problem prompt completely, believing that calculating acceleration was the goal.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires initializing a sum, reading 5 integers (preferably within a loop), checking each integer for evenness using the modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), and accumulating the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Class name is 'AccelerationCalculator'
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Performs a physics calculation (acceleration) instead of summation/filtering
Lack of any loop or conditional logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Missubmission (submitting the wrong file) or total failure to read and comprehend the instructions for Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement for Q1 and ensure you submit the correct program file. The required program must use loops, conditional statements, and an accumulator to process 5 integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code is syntactically a working Java program, but it literally solves a different problem based on the class name, variable names, and explicit arithmetic formula used.

evidence.note: The class name and structure immediately indicate the code is for an unrelated task (Acceleration Calculator).
The code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers, violating the input requirement.
This arithmetic calculation is for acceleration, not for accumulating the sum of even numbers. This also shows the absence of a loop or conditional logic.

misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The program is written to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, rather than reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user and compute the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program reads only three values, not five
Variable names and output text refer to acceleration, not sums or even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reused or copied code from a different textbook/example problem about acceleration instead of implementing the required sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully and start from an empty main method. Design the program around the required behavior: reading 5 integers and summing the even ones. Avoid reusing unrelated example code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompts, and formulas are specific to an acceleration example and do not mention integers, sums, or even numbers.

evidence.note: Class name, prompt, and variables clearly target an acceleration problem with v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers.
Program computes and prints an acceleration value, not a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Does not read 5 integers as required
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers, the program reads exactly three double values representing v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading three numeric inputs (v0, v1, t) is sufficient for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read 5 separate integer values from the user, regardless of how they are entered on the line.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble instead of nextInt
Only three calls to input.nextDouble()
No mechanism to read exactly 5 numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Followed the input pattern from an acceleration example rather than designing input handling to match the requirement of 5 integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a loop or repeated input statements so that you call input.nextInt() five times to read 5 integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are exactly three input reads using nextDouble and no attempt to read 5 values or use integers.

evidence.note: Only three inputs are read, all as doubles, and the prompt refers to v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process a fixed number of inputs; it simply reads three values once.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is enough to call nextDouble a few times directly without a loop for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle exactly 5 numbers in a scalable way, a loop (for or while) should iterate 5 times to read and process each integer.
symptoms: No for or while loops present in the program
Inputs are read via three separate statements only once
There is no structure to iterate five times
misconceptions.root_cause: Program structure copied from an example that only needed three inputs, so no loop was introduced to generalize to 5 values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that runs 5 times. Inside the loop, read one integer each iteration and update any necessary accumulators.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code base has no loop constructs at all, and all input is handled with three sequential statements.

evidence.note: Input handling is done with three direct calls and there is no loop anywhere in main.

misconceptions.name: No conditional or modulo check to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even; it performs a continuous arithmetic formula for acceleration instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this task, I only need to compute (v1 - v0) / t; there is no need to test numbers with conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, the program must use a conditional statement (e.g., if) with a modulo operation (n % 2 == 0) to detect even integers before adding them to the sum.
symptoms: No if statements in the code
No use of the % (modulo) operator
Arithmetic expression is a single formula unrelated to even/odd checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Student implemented an entirely different formula-based problem and did not consider the need to filter inputs by parity.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, use an if statement like `if (n % 2 == 0)` to check if it’s even before adding it to your sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals or modulo operations, and all operations relate only to the acceleration formula.

evidence.note: Only a single arithmetic formula is used; there is no conditional logic or modulo operation to filter even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator for sum of even numbers and incorrect output message
misconceptions.description: The program does not maintain a running sum of even integers; instead, it computes a one-time acceleration value and prints an acceleration-related message.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should compute one formula result (acceleration) and print it once.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should accumulate the sum of all even numbers encountered and then print `Sum of even numbers: <value>` at the end.
symptoms: No integer sum variable initialized to 0
No repeated addition to an accumulator
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student followed an example focused on computing and printing a single formula result rather than designing an accumulator-based solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Declare an integer variable `sum = 0;` before the loop. Each time you read an even integer, add it to `sum`. After processing all 5 numbers, print `Sum of even numbers: ` followed by `sum`.
related_concepts: Formatting output messages to match requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is a single double result variable and no sign of an accumulator or correct final message.

evidence.note: Program computes and prints an acceleration instead of accumulating a sum of even numbers and printing that sum.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for a completely different task (Acceleration Calculator) instead of the requested task (Sum of Even Numbers). The submitted code bears no relationship to the instructions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or copied unrelated boilerplate. They believe this code satisfies the requirement to find the sum of 5 even integers, which it does not.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly 5 integers, use a loop/repetition structure, check for parity (evenness), and accumulate a sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration, not sum
Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present
No conditional logic for checking even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Missubmission or failure to read/understand the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement carefully and rewrite the entire program to solve the 'Sum of Even Numbers' task. You need to use a loop and the modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code implements an entirely different, identifiable task (calculating acceleration) than the one requested (summing even numbers). This is undeniable.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different purpose.
Calculates acceleration, which is irrelevant to finding the sum of even numbers.
